comments.body: What's the motivation for removing `to_text` here?
The first commit of this pull-request reverts a2596f888700c7d97201c269ce6348830b46d6de.

Using Python 3 and a2596f8, `ansible-config -c ansible.cfg dump` remains unusable. a2596f8 fixes an exception but the configuration file is still not read: [`ConfigParser.read`](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/configparser.py#L690) doesn't support bytes:
```
(Pdb) bt
  ansible/bin/ansible-config(118)<module>()
-> exit_code = cli.run()
  ansible/lib/ansible/cli/config.py(72)run()
-> self.config = ConfigManager(self.config_file)
  ansible/lib/ansible/config/manager.py(202)__init__()
-> self._parse_config_file()
  ansible/lib/ansible/config/manager.py(220)_parse_config_file()
-> self._parser.read(cfile)
> /usr/lib/python3.6/configparser.py(696)read()
-> with open(filename, encoding=encoding) as fp:
```
```
(Pdb) filenames
b'path/to/ansible.cfg'
(Pdb) [x for x in filenames]
[... 47, 97, 110, 115, 105, 98, 108, 101, 46, 99, 102, 103]
```
Avoiding `bytes` conversion fixes both problem, then the conversion added by a2596f8 becomes useless.
Alright, the "avoiding `bytes` conversion fixes both problems" is the part I didn't realize. :+1:

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +355,359 @@                    value = defs[config].get('default')
                    origin = 'default'
                    # skip typing as this is a temlated default that will be resolved later in constants, which has needed vars
                    if plugin_type is None and isinstance(value, string_types) and (value.startswith('{{') and value.endswith('}}')):
                        return value, origin

comments.body: I'm confused by this change, but I don't think it breaks anything since `keywords` is unused in our docs. There are some uses of `keyword` but those all appear to be commented out. I don't know what the vision was. Could break 3rd party things if they discovered it here or [here](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/27c7d5bb01f15dc89021a6019c07c10a03ed7035/lib/ansible/cli/doc.py#L488)?
To be honest I have no context about this change.  It was made 2 authors prior to me.
Do tests pass without it? It seems unnecessary for this feature.
Ah, I think I'm wrong about that. I think my confusion came from most things relying heavily on direct. I'm still confused about `keywords` syntax but this looks necessary if using task_keys.
It does seem to be required.  Removing it and running through CI caused 63 test failures: https://app.shippable.com/github/ansible/ansible/runs/105917/summary/console

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +399,403 @@
                # use playbook keywords if you have em
                if value is None and keys and config in keys:
                    value, origin = keys[config], 'keyword'
                    origin = 'keyword: %s' % origin

comments.body: doesn't this also need to include `#`?

Python2 only supports `;` for inline comment prefixes

> Configuration files may include comments, prefixed by specific characters (# and ;). Comments may appear on their own in an otherwise empty line, or may be entered in lines holding values or section names. In the latter case, they need to be preceded by a whitespace character to be recognized as a comment. (For backwards compatibility, only ; starts an inline comment, while # does not.)
